results.title: What have you done with my country
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Douglass Baglin and Cinetel Film Production Services
results.brief_description: Shows what has happened to the land of the first Australians after the Europeans found it and settled it less than 200 years ago. It deliberates on the present state of the Aborigines who have no rights to land and whose culture is overshadowed by the white man’s. Includes readings from Kath Walker’s “We are going”, archival drawings of early European settlement, historical newsreel footage (Vietnam moratorium marches, mining and minerals boom, technological and industrial development etc.) Also emphasises the devastation to the animal world through man’s continual development of the natural environment for commercial gain. Photography by Douglass Baglin, narrated by Tim Elliott.

results.title: Surfing: the healing wave
results.creator_credit: Tim Burns, Huey Benjamin and Neugh Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Aborigines come from all over Australia to compete in this unique and colorful event - the annual indigenous surfing contest at Fingal on the East Coast. Kyle Slabb, the narrator, is a young aboriginal surfer whose clan are hosting the event. He guides the viewer around the spectacular rivers and idyllic coastal reserves of his homelands, offering insights into traditional ways, dance and ceremony, and an understanding of his struggle to preserve these values in his modern life. The film is a lively and uplifting look at the positive steps taken by an indigenous community as it strives to achieve cultural continuity for future generations.

results.title: Children of the Musgraves
results.creator_credit: Edmee Campbell-Dobbie, J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: Filmed at Ernabella Mission Station in the Musgrave Ranges, 1000 miles north of Adelaide. Shows the life of Aborigines, their schooling and play, and their assimilation to white Australian ways. They are also given time each day to follow their own cultural traditions of hunting and cooking. Narrated by J.J. Hume.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edmee Campbell-Dobbie, J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films

results.title: Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Records the 1948 joint Australian-American expedition to Arnhem Land. Shows field work of scientists collecting specimens of insects, birds, fish, mammals, flowers, vegetation, rock structures, aboriginal paintings and carvings, etc. Several scenes show aborigines in ceremonial rituals, including the dances of the great kangaroo, the water snake, and the wild honey dances. Photographed by Peter Bassett-Smith, with music by Alfred F. Hill.

results.title: Murray River quest
results.brief_description: This is the story of Australia’s greatest river seen through the eyes of two canoeists on an expedition seeking the history of the river and it’s importance in the development of Victoria and New South Wales. It tells of the Aborigines, explorers and town founders; of irrigators, woodcutters and fishermen - all those people whose lives and adventures make up the history of the Murray River.

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: part one: they must always consider us as enemies 1788-1830
results.brief_description: Soldier/Administrator David Collins, arriving in Sydney on the First Fleet is acknowledged as being the first official to acknowledge there is tension between blacks and whites in their struggle over the land. Fighting ends temporarily in Tasmania after a verbal treaty is reached acknowledging partial rights to Aborigines over the land. The Government quickly breaks this verbal promise however and the Aborigines flee into exile.
results.title_for_label: Frontier: stories from white Australia’s forgotten war: part one: they must always consider us as enemies 1788-1830

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: Part two: worse than slavery itself 1830-1860
results.brief_description: Humanitarians and missionaries begin an anti slavery plight on behalf of the Aborigines against the Crown. Despite their efforts however and a growth in national awareness, the massacres continue.

results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: part three: the government should shut its eyes 1860-1938
results.brief_description: The final part in the ‘Frontier’ series moves North to Queensland where Aboriginal resistance is high. An estimated ten thousand Aborigines lose their lives in the resistance with the law of the day, the Colonial Government, seemingly turning a blind eye. In the face of these massacres, forced assimilation and breeding out, Aborigines started to organise politically and informed white Australia they had no intention of dying out.

results.title: Namatjira the painter
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, Ralph Foster and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Traces the life and artistic development of the Aboriginal painter, the late Albert Namatjira. His environment, his introduction to painting, his subsequent success with beautifully original landscapes and his influence on fellow Aborigines are recorded. [Rev. ed. 007430]

results.title: Australian animals dreaming stories
results.brief_description: Aborigines used stories to teach their children about the laws and myths of their land. Pauline McLeod tells five stories about unique Australian animals. Each story is laced with colourful drawings. The stories featured are: ‘The Giant goanna and the black snake’; ‘The Platypus’; ‘How the kangaroo got its pouch’; ‘Why does the kookaburra laugh?’; ‘The Bunyip’.
